steps.title: The 1970s invented â€œcoolâ€â€”and many of its synonyms.
steps.content: The 1970s invented â€œcoolâ€â€”and many of its synonyms. The word â€œcoolâ€ will never go out of style, but why not shake things up a bit and use another iconic â€™70s slang word to let someone know how far out they really are? Check out these alternatives to â€œcoolâ€: [1] X Research source Bad Bomb Cool beans Fab Far out Funky Groovy Nifty Out of sight Off the hook Radical Slamminâ€™ Stellar Tubular

steps.title: Make an impression at your next party with a retro greeting or goodbye.
steps.content: Make an impression at your next party with a retro greeting or goodbye. Arrive at your next hangout in style with a â€œMy man, my man!â€ or leave your mark with a â€œPeace outâ€ when you depart. Or try out one of these other fun retro ways to say hello or goodbye: My man, my man!: a friendly way to greet a male friend Say, brothaâ€™: a friendly way to greet a male friend What it is: â€œWhatâ€™s upâ€ Whatâ€™s crackin': â€œWhatâ€™s up?â€ Catch you on the flip side: see you later (the "flip side" refers to the other side of a vinyl record) I gotta skitty: â€œI have to hurry up and goâ€ Keep on steppinâ€™: â€œKeep moving,â€ â€œGet out of hereâ€ Later days: â€œSee you laterâ€ Peace, love, and granola: a peaceful goodbye Peace out: â€œIâ€™m leavingâ€

steps.title: Get creative with your descriptions of other people.
steps.content: Get creative with your descriptions of other people. Whether you want to talk about what a hottie your crush is or dish out an insult someone will never forget, the â€˜70s has got you covered: [2] X Research source Boob tuber: someone who watches way too much TV Brick house: a super hot, curvy woman Burnout: someone who uses too many drugs (it later came to mean the experience of being exhausted from work) Casanova: a ladiesâ€™ man Couch potato: someone who spends too much time in front of the TV Dork: a nerd Dude: a guy, or a generic term to describe someone regardless of gender Foxy mama: a super hot lady Goof: a silly person Jive: dance Jive turkey: someone who tries to be cool, but fails Lame-o: someone who's really not cool Putz: a klutz Space cadet: an airhead Square: a conformist; somebody who's boring Stone fox: a really attractive woman Youngblood: a young man; a boy

steps.title: Be ready to boogie the night away with these slang disco terms!
steps.content: Be ready to boogie the night away with these slang disco terms! A special subset of 1970s slang is disco slang, or slang you might use when youâ€™re getting your groove on to ABBA or the BeeGees. Try one of these words or phrases: Boogie: to dance Boogie down: to dance enthusiastically Closet disco queen: someone who dances in private at home, but not in public Get your groove on: to dance Groovy: cool

steps.title: Hold an entire convo in '70s-speak with these phrases.
steps.content: Hold an entire convo in '70s-speak with these phrases. Spice up your everyday chitchat with a few vintage questions and turns of phrase, like these: Can you dig it?: â€œDo you understand?â€ Catch my drift?: "Do you get it?" Copacetic: "Not a problem" Do me a solid: "Can you do me a favor?" Do you copy?: "Do you understand me?" Flower power: "Choose love over peace" Hertz donut: Part of a joke in which you ask someone if theyâ€™d like a â€œHertz donut,â€ and when they say yes, you punch them in the arm and say, â€œHurts, donâ€™t it?â€ (Donâ€™t do this) Jeepers creepers!: "Oh, my goodness!" Keep on truckin': "Hang in there" Mind your potatoes: "Stay in your lane!" Sound as a pound: going well (as in "How are you?" "Sound as a pound") Stop digging in my Kool-Aid: "Mind your own business!" Take a chill pill: "Chill out!" Ten-four, good buddy: "Yes" What's your twenty?: "Where are you?" You decent?: "Are you dressed?" or "May I come in your room?" You jivin' yet?: "Are you having a nice time?"

steps.title: Add these other 1970s slang terms to your everyday vocab.
steps.content: Add these other 1970s slang terms to your everyday vocab. Not every slang word or phrase can be categorizedâ€”some are just their own brand of retro weirdness! Check out these popular â€™70s slang phrases to describe particular experiences or activities: Book it: to run away quickly, especially from law enforcement Bummer: a disappointment Crib: home or place of residence Deep-six: to get rid of something Down with: OK with Fake me out: trick me Flat leaver: to ditch someone to hang out with someone cooler Freaky deaky: very odd or strange Go bananas: to go crazy, let loose Good vibes: positive energy Guilt trip: excessive remorse over something due to someone else's shaming Hairy eyeball: a nasty glare Jive-talking: spouting nonsense The lowdown: all the information; the truth The man: authority figure, usually someone in law enforcement Pad: where someone lives Primo: excellent Shagginâ€™ wagon: 1970s van with a bed in the back ğŸ‘€ The skinny: the real story; the whole truth Stoked: super excited Threads: apparel; clothes Tighty-whitey: men's underwear To the max: to the extreme Wedgie: the act of pulling someone's underwear up between their buttocks
